data.text:
A trip to Nicaragua means that youll have different currencies in your pocket. Official one is the C贸rdoba Oro (NIO), divided into 100 Centavos. It was introduced in 1912 and replaced the formerly used Peso. It is named after Francisco Hern谩ndez de C贸rdoba, the founder of the country. Due to inflation the currency had to be re-issued in 1988 and 1990. As often in Latin America, there is a secondary currency that is widely accepted. In Nicaragua this is the US-Dollar (USD) that you can withdraw at ATMs next to C贸rdobas and which you can use nearly everywhere.

Paying in Nicaragua is mostly hassle-free. You can use credit cards and in a lot of super markets, at gas stations and in most hotels. VISA cards worked better than MasterCards. You can find ATMs at banks in city centers, but most often you can withdraw cash at supermarkets and gas stations (which is a bit unusual at least for a German). What youll have to live with is the uncertainty of the maximum account of USD and C贸rdobas you can withdraw; youll simply have to try it out and it differs from location to location. Which currency to use when? If youre in rather touristy places or using tourist services youll most often be asked for USD; in rural areas and untouristy places youll better go with C贸rdobas. But dont worry, theyll most often charge gringos higher prices anyway.
